aphids.name: Aphids
aphids.description: Small, soft-bodied insects that feed on plant sap. Usually green, black, or white in color.
identification: Small (1-4mm) soft-bodied insects
Cluster on new growth, stems, and leaves
Green, black, white, or gray colored
Often found with sticky honeydew secretions
May have winged or wingless forms
organic_treatments: Blast off with strong water spray
prevention: Plant companion plants like marigolds and nasturtiums
Encourage beneficial insects with diverse plantings
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
Remove weeds that harbor aphids
Use reflective mulch to confuse aphids

caterpillars.name: Caterpillars
caterpillars.description: Larvae of butterflies and moths that can cause significant damage to plants by eating leaves.
identification: Worm-like larvae with distinct head capsule
Various colors: green, brown, black, striped
6 true legs near head, prolegs on abdomen
Size varies from 1cm to 10cm depending on species
Leave behind frass (droppings)
damage: Tunnel damage in stems or fruits
organic_treatments: Use row covers during egg-laying periods
prevention: Plant diverse flowers to attract beneficial insects
Use companion planting with herbs like dill and fennel
Install bird houses to encourage natural predators
Rotate crops annually
Remove plant debris where pupae might overwinter

spider_mites.name: Spider Mites
spider_mites.description: Tiny arachnids that feed on plant cells, causing stippling and webbing on leaves.
identification: Extremely small (less than 1mm) spider-like pests
Red, yellow, or green coloration
Fine webbing on leaves and stems
Stippled or bronzed appearance on leaves
More active in hot, dry conditions
damage: Tiny yellow or white spots on leaves
organic_treatments: Strong water sprays to remove mites
prevention: Maintain adequate soil moisture
Increase air circulation around plants
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
Plant diversity to support beneficial insects
Regular monitoring, especially in hot weather

whiteflies.name: Whiteflies
whiteflies.description: Small, white flying insects that feed on plant sap and can transmit plant viruses.
identification: Small (1-2mm) white flying insects
Triangular shape when wings are folded
Fly up when plants are disturbed
Yellow, scale-like nymphs on leaf undersides
Sticky honeydew secretions
organic_treatments: Vacuum flying adults in early morning
prevention: Use reflective mulch to confuse whiteflies
Plant companion plants like marigolds
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
Remove weeds that serve as hosts
Use row covers when plants are young

scale_insects.name: Scale Insects
scale_insects.description: Small, immobile insects that attach to plant stems and leaves, feeding on sap.
identification: Small, oval or round bumps on stems and leaves
Hard or soft shell covering the insect
Brown, white, or gray colored scales
Sticky honeydew secretions
Yellowing of affected plant parts
organic_treatments: Scrape off scales with fingernail or soft brush
Dab individual scales with rubbing alcohol
prevention: Quarantine new plants before introducing to garden
Maintain proper plant spacing for air circulation
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
Regular inspection of plants
Remove heavily infested plant parts

thrips.name: Thrips
thrips.description: Tiny, slender insects that feed on plant cells, causing silvering and stippling damage.
identification: Very small (1-2mm) slender insects
Yellow, brown, or black coloration
Fringed wings
Fast-moving when disturbed
Silvery stippling damage on leaves
damage: Black specks of excrement on leaves
prevention: Maintain proper soil moisture
Use row covers during vulnerable periods
Plant diverse flowers to attract beneficials
Remove weeds and plant debris
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
